text: {{Infobox writer | name = Marie-Claire Blais | image = Marie-Claire Blais 2010.jpg | alt = | caption = Blais at the 2010 Montréal Book Fair | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = Québec, Québec, Canada | death_date = | death_place = Key West, Florida, U.S. | resting_place = | occupation = Author, playwright | language = | nationality = Canadian | citizenship = | education = Université de Montréal (2002–2003), Université de Montréal (1993–1997), Université Laval | alma_mater = | period = | genre = Romance, theater, screenplay, poetry, essay | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = Governor General's Award for French-language fiction, Guggenheim Fellowship for Creative Arts, US & Canada | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} Marie-Claire Blais, (5 October 1939 – 30 November 2021) was a Canadian writer, novelist, poet, and playwright. She wrote novels, plays, poetry, newspaper articles, radio dramas, and scripts for television. Some of her works included La Belle Bête (1959), The Manuscripts of Pauline Archange (1968), Deaf to the City (1979), and a ten-volume series Soifs written between 1995 and 2018. Blais died 30 November 2021, in Key West, Florida at the age of 82.Deborah Dundas, "Québec writer Marie-Claire Blais, once the enfant terrible of French Canadian fiction, has died at the age of 82" Toronto Star 1 December 2021 == Related pages == *List of poets from North America ==References== Category:1939 births Category:2021 deaths Category:Canadian poets Category:Canadian novelists Category:Canadian playwrights Category:Canadian journalists Category:Writers from Quebec City
